across.text: Woman with capital touring area round Chilean port
across.explanation: VALPARAISO(i.e. “Chilean port”). Solution is VAL (i.e. “woman’s” name) followed by PARIS (i.e. “capital” city of France) once wrapped around A (a recognised abbreviation of “area”), then O (i.e. “round”), like so: VAL-PAR(A)IS-O. …aaaand straight to Bradford’s the moment I saw “port”. I’m sure it’s lovely there but life’s too short for clues like this. Also, I spy a French reference, so…

across.text: Bishop, say, taking whisky and flavoured toffee
across.explanation: BUTTERSCOTCH(i.e. “flavoured toffee”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “bishop” used in chess) followed by UTTER (i.e. “say”), then SCOTCH (i.e. “whisky”).

across.text: Piece of fruit from damaged crate in square
across.explanation: NECTARINE(i.e. “piece of fruit”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “damaged”) of CRATE placed “in” NINE (i.e. “square” of three), like so: N(ECTAR)INE.

across.text: Man absorbing girl’s turn of phrase
across.explanation: IDIOM(i.e. “turn of phrase”). Solution is DI (i.e. “girl’s” name – another one) placed in or “absorbed” by IOM (a recognised abbreviation of the Isle of “Man”), like so: I(DI)OM.

across.text: An accommodating type leaving house for studio
across.explanation: ATELIER(i.e. “studio”). Solution is A HOTELIER (i.e. “an accommodating type”) with the HO removed (indicated by “leaving house” – HO being a recognised abbreviation of “house”), like so: A-TELIER.

across.text: Disturbed by Shaw play, throw plans into confusion
across.explanation: UPSET THE APPLECART(i.e. “throw plans into confusion”). Solution is UPSET (i.e. “disturbed”) followed by THE APPLECART (i.e. “Shaw play”).

across.text: Daughter introducing well-ventilated source of milk products
across.explanation: DAIRY(i.e. “of milk products”). Solution is D (a recognised abbreviation of “daughter”) followed by AIRY (i.e. “well-ventilated”).

across.text: Like bristly growth displayed by learner in squat
across.explanation: STUBBLY(i.e. “like bristly growth”). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner”) placed “in” STUBBY (i.e. “squat”), like so: STUBB(L)Y.

across.text: Struggle ultimately set American ship against the French
across.explanation: TUSSLE(i.e. “struggle”). Solution is T (i.e. “ultimately set”, i.e. the last letter of “set”) followed by USS (i.e. “American ship”, short for United States Ship or Steamer), then LE (i.e. “the French”, i.e. the masculine form of “the” in French). Another French reference, so…

across.text: Like erupting mountain with very old clan oddly in charge
across.explanation: VOLCANIC(i.e. “like erupting mountain”). Solution is V (a recognised abbreviation of “very”) followed by O (ditto “old”), then an anagram (indicated by “oddly”) of CLAN, then IC (a recognised abbreviation of “in charge”), like so: V-O-LCAN-IC.

across.text: Examine first of patients overcome by bug
across.explanation: INSPECT(i.e. “examine”). Solution is P (i.e. “first [letter] of patients”) placed in or “overcome by” INSECT (i.e. “bug”), like so: INS(P)ECT.

across.text: Tramp crossing wooded hollow, initially identifying gumtree
across.explanation: BDELLIUM(i.e. “gumtree”). Solution is BUM (i.e. “tramp”) wrapped around or “crossing” DELL (i.e. “wooded hollow”) and I (i.e. “initially identifying”, i.e. the first letter of “identifying”), like so: B(DELL-I)UM. Another win for my Bradford’s. I had a feeling this was going to be another of those made-to-fit solutions setters reach for when they can’t be arsed reworking an awkward area of the grid.

across.text: Cook meal finally rejected by weight watcher
across.explanation: SIMMER(i.e. “cook”). Solution is SLIMMER (i.e. “weight watcher”) with the L removed (indicated by “meal finally rejected”, i.e. the last letter of “meal”).

across.text: Eerie quality of spoken words framed by good entertainers
across.explanation: GHOSTLINESS(i.e. “eerie quality”). Solution is LINES (i.e. “spoken words”) placed in or “framed by” G (a recognised abbreviation of “good”) and HOSTS (i.e. “entertainers”), like so: G-HOST(LINES)S.

across.text: Republican priest with capacity for trustworthiness
across.explanation: RELIABILITY(i.e. “trustworthiness”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “Republican”) followed by ELI (i.e. biblical “priest”) and ABILITY (i.e. “capacity”).

across.text: Mess one clears up if only slight
across.explanation: SUPERFICIAL(i.e. “only slight”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “mess”) of I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and CLEARS UP IF.

across.text: In cold season attorney secures revolutionary outer garment
across.explanation: WINDCHEATER(i.e. “outer garment”). Solution is WINTER (i.e. “cold season”) “in” which is placed DA (i.e. “attorney”, specifically a District Attorney) once it has been wrapped around or “securing” CHE Guevara (i.e. “revolutionary”), like so: WIN(D(CHE)A)TER.

across.text: Invested in university, died outside it
across.explanation: ENDUED(i.e. “invested in”). Solution is U (a recognised abbreviation of “university”) with ENDED (i.e. “died”) placed “outside it”, like so: END(U)ED.

across.text: Books seized by leading press chief stupefied with drink
across.explanation: BESOTTED(i.e. “stupefied with drink”). Solution is OT (i.e. “books”, specifically the Old Testament of The Bible) placed in or “seized by” BEST ED (i.e. “leading press chief”, ED being short for an editor), like so: BES(OT)T-ED.

across.text: Head across border to find top cleric
across.explanation: PRIMATE(i.e. “top cleric”). Solution is PATE (i.e. “head”) wrapped around or placed “across” RIM (i.e. “border”), like so: P(RIM)ATE.

across.text: Records produced by shrewd American composer
across.explanation: ARCHIVES(i.e. “records”). Solution is ARCH (i.e. “shrewd”) followed by Charles IVES (i.e. “American composer”).

across.text: Part of fireplace king introduced to old PM
across.explanation: HEARTH(i.e. “part of fireplace”). Solution is R (i.e. “king”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of the LatinRex) placed in or “introduced to” Edward HEATH (i.e. “old PM”), like so: HEA(R)TH.

across.text: Good fortune currently attending this old siege city
across.explanation: LUCKNOW(i.e. “old siege city” during the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Yes, of course I looked it up). Solution is LUCK (i.e. “good fortune”) followed by NOW (i.e. “currently”).

across.text: Senseless importuners dismissed from Macbeth’s castle
across.explanation: INANE(i.e. “senseless”). Solution is DUNSINANE (i.e. “Macbeth’s castle”) with the DUNS removed (indicated by “importuners dismissed” – a variant meaning of DUN is one who pesters another for payment).

across.text: More distinguished chap at NW city – or larger NW area
across.explanation: GREATER MANCHESTER(i.e. “NW area” of England). Solution is GREATER (i.e. “more distinguished”) followed by MAN (i.e. “chap”) and CHESTER (i.e. “NW city” of England).

across.text: Additional article – by him, do we assume?
across.explanation: ANOTHER(i.e. “additional”). Solution is A (i.e. “article”, being a word like a, an or the) followed by NOT HER (i.e. “him, do we assume?”).

across.text: A retired man from a foreign land
across.explanation: ALIEN(i.e. “from a foreign land”). Solution A followed by NEIL (i.e. “man’s” name) once reversed (indicated by “retired”), like so: A-LIEN.

across.text: Plant hanging down at end of bay, perhaps?
across.explanation: HORSETAIL. Solution satisfies “plant” and playfully “hanging down at end of bay, perhaps” – referencing a type of horse.

across.text: Text originator’s certificate, cornier western included
across.explanation: SCRIPTWRITER(i.e. “text originator”). Solution is SCRIP (i.e. share “certificate”) followed by TRITER (i.e. “cornier”) once wrapped around or “including” W (a recognised abbreviation of “western”), like so: SCRIP-T(W)RITER.

across.text: One who pledges to deal with people who are late?
across.explanation: UNDERTAKER. Clue plays on two meanings of the word, i.e. one who undertakes to deal with something, and someone who handles the dead, or “late”. You get the idea.

down.text: Defeating first two in quiz, disappearing outside
down.explanation: VANQUISHING(i.e. “defeating”). Solution is QU (i.e. “first two [letters] in quiz”) with VANISHING (i.e. “disappearing”) placed “outside” of it, like so: VAN(QU)ISHING.

down.text: Place in which stripper wastes time?
down.explanation: LOCUS(i.e. a position or “place”). Solution is LOCUST (i.e. “stripper” of plant life) with the T removed (indicated by “wastes time” – T being a recognised abbreviation of “time”).

down.text: Flexible notice father put up on board
down.explanation: ADAPTABLE(i.e. “flexible”). Solution is AD (i.e. “notice”, short for advertisement) followed by PA (i.e. “father”) once reversed (indicated by “put up” – this being a down clue), then TABLE (i.e. “board”), like so: AD-AP-TABLE.

down.text: Remains extremely lazy about letter? It’s how some 39s behave
down.explanation: APISHLY(i.e. “how some 39s behave” – the solution to 39a being PRIMATE). Solution is ASH (i.e. “remains”) and LY (i.e. “extremely lazy”, i.e. the first and last letters of “lazy”) all wrapped “about” PI (i.e. “letter”, specifically the sixteenth letter of the Greek alphabet), like so: A(PI)SH-LY.

down.text: Agitation at confining king in royal house once
down.explanation: STEWART(i.e. “royal house once”). Solution is STEW (i.e. “agitation”) followed by AT once wrapped around R (i.e. “king”, short forRex, covered earlier), like so: STEW-A(R)T.

down.text: Like protozoans, extremely unusual in college wine vault
down.explanation: UNICELLULAR(i.e. “like protozoans”). Solution is UL (i.e. “extremely unusual”, i.e. the first and last letters of “unusual”) placed “in” UNI (i.e. “college”, short for university) and CELLAR (i.e. “wine vault”), like so: UNI-CELL(UL)AR.

down.text: Male Abyssinian, perhaps, completely taking in host?
down.explanation: TOMCAT(i.e. “male Abyssinian, perhaps” – other breeds are available). Solution is TO A T (i.e. “completely”) wrapped around or “taking in” MC (i.e. “host”, or Master of Ceremonies), like so: TO-(MC)-A-T.

down.text: Feedback on beginning of play being broadcast
down.explanation: REACTION(i.e. “feedback”). Solution is RE (i.e. “on” or regarding – think email replies) followed by ACT I (i.e. “beginning of play”) and ON (i.e. “being broadcast”).

down.text: I feed such nice crumbles, being head cook
down.explanation: CHEF DE CUISINE(i.e. “head cook”). “Crumbles” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of I FEED SUCH NICE. Another French reference, so…

down.text: Boy king, one talking tediously about one’s schooling
down.explanation: TUITION(i.e. “schooling”). Not 100% on this one, but for what it’s worth my solution is TUT (i.e. “boy king”, short for Tutankhamun), followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and ON (i.e. “talking tediously”, as in going on an on about something). This is all then wrapped “about” I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one” – again), like so: TU(I)T-I-ON. A bit naff, assuming I’ve got it right.

down.text: Fly spicy food around south in frantic haste
down.explanation: HURRY-SCURRY(i.e. “frantic haste”). Solution is HURRY (i.e. “fly”) followed by CURRY (i.e. “spicy food”) once all wrapped “around” S (a recognised abbreviation of “south”), like so: HURRY-(S)-CURRY.

down.text: Oust inspector’s force on ship
down.explanation: DISPOSSESS(i.e. “oust”). Solution is DI’S (i.e. “inspector’s”, specifically a Detective Inspector) followed by POSSE (i.e. a “force” of constables) and SS (i.e. “ship”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a steamship).

down.text: Allowed to continue, having misguidedly posted pun
down.explanation: UNSTOPPED(i.e. “allowed to continue”). “Misguidedly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of POSTED PUN.

down.text: Old-fashioned occupation duke summarised
down.explanation: OUTLINED(i.e. “summarised”). Solution is OUT (i.e. “old-fashioned”) followed by LINE (i.e. “occupation”) and D (a recognised abbreviation of “duke”).

down.text: Dimly illuminated legal document briefly digested by singer
down.explanation: TWILIT(i.e. “dimly illuminated”). Solution is WILL (i.e. “legal document”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “briefly”) and the remainder placed in or “digested by” TIT (i.e. “singer” or songbird), like so: T(WIL)IT.

down.text: Farm animals are seen around most of his worker’s homes
down.explanation: BEEHIVES(i.e. “worker’s homes”). Solution is BEEVES (i.e. “farm animals” – a new one on me, apparently after a plural of beef) wrapped “around” HI (i.e. “most of his”, i.e. the word HIS with the last letter removed), like so: BEE(HI)VES.

down.text: Letter-carrier (man, we hear) represented in art
down.explanation: MAIL TRAIN(i.e. “letter-carrier”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “we hear”) of MALE (i.e. “man”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “represented”) of IN ART.

down.text: Reckless general’s assistant enthralled by chart
down.explanation: MADCAP(i.e. “reckless”). Solution is ADC (i.e. “general’s assistant”, specifically an Aide-De-Camp) placed in or “enthralled by” MAP (i.e. “chart”), like so: M(ADC)AP.

down.text: Summons to vote, fixing pint while here
down.explanation: THREE-LINE WHIP(i.e. “summons to vote”). “Fixing” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PINT WHILE HERE.

down.text: Female childminder talked of problem reversing mischief
down.explanation: SHENANIGANS(i.e. “mischief”). Solution is SHE (i.e. “female”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “talked of”) of NANNY, then SNAG (i.e. “problem”) once “reversed”, like so: SHE-NANI-GANS.

down.text: Most unrestricted widespread plant
down.explanation: LOOSESTRIFE(i.e. “plant”). Solution is LOOSEST (i.e. “most unrestricted”) followed by RIFE (i.e. “widespread”).

down.text: Frown at ratter regularly loose in dockyard area
down.explanation: WATERFRONT(i.e. “dockyard area”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “loose”) of FROWN AT and RTE (i.e. “ratter regularly”, i.e. every other letter ofRATTER).

down.text: Singer distributed ale brewed in outskirts of Rochester
down.explanation: REED WARBLER(i.e. “singer”, another songbird). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “distributed”) of ALE BREWED placed “in” RR (i.e. “outskirts of Rochester”, i.e. the first and last letters of “Rochester”), like so: R(EEDWARBLE)R.

down.text: Popular old pope’s description of stormy weather?
down.explanation: INCLEMENT(i.e. “description of stormy weather”). Solution is IN (i.e. “trendy”) followed by CLEMENT (i.e. “old pope” – there’s been a few Clements to choose from).

down.text: Evade argument, creating shrubby border round field
down.explanation: HEDGEROW(i.e. “shrubby border round field”). Solution is HEDGE (i.e. “evade” or to be evasive in an argument) followed by ROW (i.e. “argument”).

down.text: Outcry about affair involving Liberal leader
down.explanation: CLAMOUR(i.e. “outcry”). Solution is C (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) and AMOUR (i.e. “affair”) all wrapped around or “involving” L (a recognised abbreviation of “Liberal”), like so: C-(L)-AMOUR.

down.text: Governor at that time shielding a nonbeliever
down.explanation: HEATHEN(i.e. “nonbeliever”). Solution is HE (i.e. “governor”, short for His Excellency if you go in for such bowing and scraping) and THEN (i.e. “at that time”) all wrapped around or “shielding” A, like so: HE-(A)-THEN.

down.text: Picked up escaped bird of prey in Swiss canton
down.explanation: LUCERNE(i.e. “Swiss canton”, and very nice it is too). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “picked up” of LOOSE (i.e. “escaped”) followed by ERNE (i.e. “bird of prey”).

down.text: Asian writer turned boxer
down.explanation: NEPALI(i.e. “Asian”). Solution is PEN (i.e. “writer”) reversed (indicated by “turned”) and followed by Muhammad ALI (i.e. “boxer”), like so: NEP-ALI.

down.text: Equestrian equipment found outside entrance to rural path
down.explanation: TRACK(i.e. “path”). Solution is TACK (i.e. “equestrian equipment”) wrapped around or “found outside” R (i.e. “entrance to rural”, i.e. the first letter of “rural”), like so: T(R)ACK.
